page.title: 01East of the Kilmartin Valley
page.content: The land rises steeply from the Kilmartin Valley. The highest point is 231mtrs in the northwest of the area . It falls sharply in the east of the area to the single track road which runs northward, skirting Loch Leathan. Forestry plantations grow on the nort, west and south of the loch. The remainder of the area is rough grassland, grazed by sheep. Bracken grows on the ridges and slopes of the ground. The land is uninhabited now ecxcept for one farm, Klibride, and a new cottage situated in a glen where the land is more fertile, and four houses built by the Forestry Comm., in the southwest of the area. Some of the forests are fringed by deciduous trees. A few weather-beaten trees survive beside streams and the farm is surrounded by woodland.
